text:
The time from Tomfs divorce through his leaving
Radio House was one of great emotional upheaval*
Perhaps more so for him than it would have been
for a man of lesser stature. But at no time when
crisis seemed to be surmounted only by crisis, did
Tom Rishworth loose sight of, or neglect his duty
to Radio House and to Educational Radio. At no times
did his personal problem fog his thinking about the
jobs at hand. I know. I was there. I directed him
in a show the day he announced quietly to the staff
that he and Jane were getting a divorce. I did a
remote broadcast with him the day after the President’s
office informed Tom that he "was under investigation,’1
Check with Marye Benjamin as to Tom’s carrying out of
duties up to the time of his leaving. Check with A1
Johnson, Chairman of the U. T. Drama Department. Check
with Bill Cavness, another script writer there. Ask
Dr. E. P. Conkle or Tom Rousse if the Radio Committee
was dissatisfied with the calibre of Tom’s work. Ask
any psychiatrist how much groundless, personal slander
any one man can stand before his own judgement takes
him to another place.
AJ the time of Tom’s leaving he had promised Hugh
Procter, Texas Education Agency, six additional shows
in the Radio House series "Is Anybody Home." A lesser
man would have turned the remaining six shows back
into the Radio House hopper. Tom promised Procter
that since his voice was on the first six tapes, he
would, as soon as he obtained tape equipment, record
the final six shows. This he did at Interlochen.
Tom kept his promise, prompted by his belief in the
things he had built at Radio House, and Procter re¬
ceived the shows well ahead of air time.
I cite this to further my point that emotional upheavals
have not impaired Tom Rishworth1s capability. Tom’s
capability stems from a thorough knowledge of the
tools of radio AND from a deep and sincere belief in
radio as a social and educational force. Tom’s personal
problems are his own, but they will never overshadow
his ability, faith, and vigor for his chosen field.
Ask any of us who have been close enough to Tom to
know.
Sincerely,
R. C. Norris
